articles.headline: Politics Permeates Anti-Corruption Drive in China
articles.snippet: Some critics have wondered if Beijing’s crackdown on executives was an excuse by the Communist Party to eliminate rivals.
articles.abstract: Some critics have wondered if Beijing’s crackdown on executives was an excuse by the Communist Party to eliminate rivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  Shortly after Huang Guangyu was named the second richest man in China by Forbes last October, the 39-year-old entrepreneur disappeared.

articles.headline: Bernanke: Greenback’s New Father
articles.snippet: The Fed chairman’s reputation will rest on whether he can right the economy without undermining confidence in the dollar.
articles.abstract: The Fed chairman’s reputation will rest on whether he can right the economy without undermining confidence in the dollar.
articles.lead_paragraph: Six months after the financial world seemed to be coming to an end, the world’s economies appear to be recovering. Banks that seemed to be on the brink of failure less than a year ago are now able to pay back investments made by the Treasury.

articles.headline: Advisers to Obama Divided on Size of Afghan Force
articles.snippet: Administration officials have begun what one called a “healthy debate” about what the priorities should be and whether more forces would help achieve them.
articles.abstract: Administration officials have begun what one called a “healthy debate” about what the priorities should be and whether more forces would help achieve them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The military’s anticipated request for more troops to combat the insurgency in Afghanistan has divided senior advisers to President Obama as they try to determine the proper size and mission of the American effort there, officials said Thursday.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Elisabeth Bumiller

articles.headline: Firefighters Become Medics to the Poor
articles.snippet: In Washington, about 80 percent of the calls handled by Engine Company 10 are for medical emergencies.
articles.abstract: In Washington, about 80 percent of the calls handled by Engine Company 10 are for medical emergencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Peeling off his latex gloves after treating a 4-year-old boy having a severe asthma attack, J. R. Muyleart sighed with a touch of frustration. It was 3 a.m. and in the past 24-hour shift, Mr. Muyleart, a firefighter, had responded to at least one emergency call per hour.

articles.headline: Inquiry Stokes Unease Over Trading Firms That Shape Markets
articles.snippet: The government has released transcripts and taped conversations to back up its allegations that one trader, Optiver, profited by manipulating oil prices.
articles.abstract: The government has released transcripts and taped conversations to back up its allegations that one trader, Optiver, profited by manipulating oil prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  Its superfast, supersecret oil trading software was called the Hammer.

articles.headline: Some Parents Oppose Obama School Speech
articles.snippet: Conservative parents have accused the president of trying to indoctrinate their children with socialist ideas.
articles.abstract: Conservative parents have accused the president of trying to indoctrinate their children with socialist ideas.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  President Obama’s plan to deliver a speech to public school students on Tuesday has set off a revolt among conservative parents, who have accused the president of trying to indoctrinate their children with socialist ideas and are asking school officials to excuse the children from listening.
articles.byline: By James C. McKinley Jr. and Sam Dillon

articles.headline: China and India Dispute Enclave on Edge of Tibet
articles.snippet: Relations between China and India have soured over a patch of border land that has a Tibetan cultural heritage.
articles.abstract: Relations between China and India have soured over a patch of border land that has a Tibetan cultural heritage.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAWANG, India  This is perhaps the most militarized Buddhist enclave in the world.

articles.headline: New Snag for Oracle in Sun Deal
articles.snippet: Europeans are concerned that the combination could squelch the growth of a popular, free corporate database program owned by Sun.
articles.abstract: Europeans are concerned that the combination could squelch the growth of a popular, free corporate database program owned by Sun.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS  European regulators delayed the proposed takeover of Sun Microsystems by the software company Oracle on Thursday, indicating that the combination could squelch the growth of a popular, free corporate database program owned by Sun.

articles.headline: Sawyer Shift Creates Gap in Morning
articles.snippet: An ABC executive says “big changes are to come” at “Good Morning America” as Diane Sawyer moves to “World News.”
articles.abstract: An ABC executive says “big changes are to come” at “Good Morning America” as Diane Sawyer moves to “World News.”
articles.lead_paragraph: When David Westin solved his evening news problem with the promotion of the “Good Morning America” co-host Diane Sawyer this week, he created a much more onerous problem for himself in the morning.
articles.byline: By Brian Stelter and Bill Carter

articles.headline: Judges’ Frustration Grows With Mortgage Servicers
articles.snippet: Consumers are succumbing to foreclosure and bankruptcy proceedings as they — and frustrated judges — wait for responses on loan modifications.
articles.abstract: Consumers are succumbing to foreclosure and bankruptcy proceedings as they — and frustrated judges — wait for responses on loan modifications.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX  Bobbi Giguere had no luck in securing a loan modification from her mortgage servicer, Wells Fargo. For months, she had sent the bank the financial documents it requested to process her modification. But each time she called to check on the request, she was told to send her paperwork again.

articles.headline: NATO Strike Magnifies Divide on Afghan War
articles.snippet: Friday’s airstrike raised questions about whether it violated tighter rules on the use of aerial bombardment.
articles.abstract: Friday’s airstrike raised questions about whether it violated tighter rules on the use of aerial bombardment.
articles.lead_paragraph: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan  A NATO airstrike on Friday exploded two fuel tankers that had been hijacked by the Taliban, setting off competing claims about how many among the scores of dead were civilians and raising questions about whether the strike violated tightened rules on the use of aerial bombardment.
articles.byline: By Stephen Farrell and Richard A. Oppel Jr

articles.headline: In Unemployment Report, Signs of a Jobless Recovery
articles.snippet: The loss of 216,000 jobs in August, which pushed the jobless rate in the U.S. to 9.7 percent, suggested that companies are not aggressively hiring despite signs of recovery.
articles.abstract: The loss of 216,000 jobs in August, which pushed the jobless rate in the U.S. to 9.7 percent, suggested that companies are not aggressively hiring despite signs of recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: The unemployment rate surged to 9.7 percent in August, signaling that joblessness and financial anxiety were likely to endure in millions of American homes for many months.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman and Jack Healy
